metadata.title: Structural analysis of SARS-CoV-2 and predictions of the human interactome 2 3

body_text.text: To analyze SARS-CoV-2 structure (reference Wuhan strain MN908947.3), we employed CROSS 12 105 to predict the double-and single-stranded content of RNA genomes such as HIV-1 13 . We found the 106 highest density of double-stranded regions in the 5' (nucleotides 1-253), membrane M protein 107 (nucleotides 26523-27191), spike S protein (nucleotides 23000-24000), and nucleocapsid N protein 108 (nucleotides 2874-29533; Fig. 1 ) 26 . The lowest density of double-stranded regions were observed 109 at nucleotides 6000-6250 and 20000-21500 and correspond to the regions between the non-110 structural proteins nsp14 and nsp15 and the upstream region of the spike surface protein S (Fig. 1) 111 26 . In addition to the maximum corresponding to nucleotides 23000-24000, the structural content of 112 spike S protein shows minima at around nucleotides 20500 and 24500 (Fig. 1) . 113 We used the Vienna method 27 to further investigate the RNA secondary structure of specific 114 regions identified with CROSS 13 . Employing a 100 nucleotide window centered around CROSS 115 maxima and minima, we found good match between CROSS scores and Vienna free energies (Fig.  116 1). Strong agreement is also observed between CROSS and Vienna positional entropy, indicating 117 that regions with the highest structural content have also the lowest structural diversity. 118 119 Our analysis suggests the presence of structural elements in SARS-CoV-2 that have evolved to 120 interact with specific human proteins 11 . Our observation is based on the assumption that structured 121 regions have an intrinsic propensity to recruit proteins 14 , which is supported by the fact that 122 structured transcripts act as scaffolds for protein assembly 15, 16 . Using Clustal W for multiple sequence alignments 28 , we observed general conservation of the 155 coding regions (Fig. 3A) . The 5' and 3' show high variability due to experimental procedures of the 156 sequencing and are discarded in this analysis 29 . One highly conserved region is between 157 nucleotides 23000 -24000 in the spike S genomic locus, while sequences up-and downstream are 158 variable (red bars in Fig. 3A) . We then used CROSSalign 13 to compare the structural content 159 (Materials and Methods). High variability of structure is observed for both the 5' and 3' and for 160 nucleotides between 21000 -22000 as well as 24000 -25000, associated with the S region (red bars 161 in Fig. 3A) . The rest of the regions are significantly conserved at a structural level (p-value < 162 0.0001; Fisher's test). 163 164 We then compared protein sequences coded by the spike S genomic locus (NCBI reference 165 QHD43416) and found that both sequence (Fig. 3A) and structure (Fig. 2) of nucleotides 23000 -166 24000 are highly conserved. The region corresponds to amino acids 330-500 that contact the host 167 receptor angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) 30 promoting infection and provoking lung injury 168 24,31 . By contrast, the region upstream of the binding site receptor ACE2 and located in 169 correspondence to the minimum of the structural profile at around nucleotides 22500-23000 ( Fig. 1 ) 170 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.28.013789 doi: bioRxiv preprint is highly variable 32 , as indicated by T-coffee multiple sequence alignments 32 (Fig. 3A) . This part of 171 the spike S region corresponds to amino acids 243-302 that in MERS-CoV binds to sialic acids 172 regulating infection through cell-cell membrane fusion ( Fig. 3B Our analysis suggests that the structural region between nucleotides 23000 and 24000 of Spike S 176 region is conserved among coronaviruses (Fig. 2) and that the binding site for ACE2 has poor 177 variation in human SARS-CoV-2 strains (Fig. 3B) . By contrast, the region upstream, which has 178 propensity to bind sialic acids 10,33,34 , showed poor structural content and high variability (Fig. 3B) . 179 180

body_text.section: Analysis of human interactions with SARS-CoV-2 identifies proteins involved in viral 181

body_text.text: In order to obtain insights on how the virus replicates in human cells, we predicted SARS-CoV-2 184 interactions with the whole RNA-binding human proteome. Following a protocol to study structural 185 conservation in viruses 13 , we first divided the Wuhan sequence in 30 fragments of 1000 nucleotides 186 each moving from the 5' to 3' and then calculated the protein-RNA interactions of each fragment 187 with catRAPID omics (3340 canonical and putative RNA-binding proteins, or RBPs, for a total 188 102000 interactions) 18 . Proteins such as Polypyrimidine tract-binding protein 1 PTBP1 (Uniprot 189 P26599) showed the highest interaction propensity (or Z-score; Materials and Methods) at the 5' 190 while others such as Heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein Q HNRNPQ (O60506) showed the 191 highest interaction propensity at the 3', in agreement with previous studies on coronaviruses (Fig. 192 4A) 35 . 193 194 For each fragment, we predicted the most significant interactions by filtering according to the Z 195 score. We used three different thresholds in ascending order of stringency: Z ³ 1.50, 1.75 and 2 196 respectively and we removed from the list the proteins that were predicted to interact promiscuously 197 with more than one fragment. Fragment 1 corresponds to the 5' and is the most contacted by RBPs 198 (around 120 with Z³2 high-confidence interactions; Fig. 4B ), which is in agreement with the 199 observation that highly structured regions attract a large number of proteins 14 . Indeed, the 5' 200 contains multiple stem loop structures that control RNA replication and transcription 36,37 . By 201 contrast, the 3' and fragment 23 (Spike S), which are still structured but to a lesser extent, attract 202 fewer proteins (10 and 5, respectively), while fragment 20 (between orf1ab and Spike S) that is 203 predicted to be unstructured, does not have binding partners. 204 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.28.013789 doi: bioRxiv preprint

The interactome of each fragment was then analysed using cleverGO, a tool for Gene Ontology 206 (GO) enrichment analysis 38 . Proteins interacting with fragments 1, 2 and 29 were associated with 207 annotations related to viral processes ( Fig. 4C ; Supp. Table 1) . Considering the three thresholds 208 applied (Materials and Methods), we found 22 viral proteins for fragment 1, 2 proteins for 209 fragment 2 and 11 proteins for fragment 29 (Fig. 4D) . 210 211 Among the high-confidence interactors of fragment 1, we discovered RBPs involved in positive 212 regulation of viral processes and viral genome replication, such as double-stranded RNA-specific 213 editase 1 ADARB1 (Uniprot P78563 39 ) and 2-5A-dependent ribonuclease RNASEL (Q05823). We 214 also identified proteins related to the establishment of integrated proviral latency, including X-ray 215 repair cross-complementing protein 5 XRCC5 (P13010) and X-ray repair cross-complementing 216 protein 6 XRCC6 (P12956; Fig. 4B ,E). Nucleolin NCL (P19338), a protein known to be involved 217 in coronavirus processing, was predicted to bind tightly to the 5' (Supp. Table 1 ) 40 . 218 219 Importantly, we found proteins related to defence response to viruses, such as ATP-dependent RNA 220 helicase DDX1 (Q92499), that are involved in negative regulation of viral genome replication. MYC and MAX that have been previously connected to viral infection processes (Fig. 4E) 44, 45 . 235
Interestingly, some proteins, including DDX1, CCNT1 and ZNF175 for fragment 1 and TRIM32 236 for fragment 2, have been shown to be necessary for HIV functions and replication inside the cell. 237
The roles of these proteins in retroviral replication are expected to be different in SARS-CoV-2. As 238 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.28.013789 doi: bioRxiv preprint SARS-CoV-2 represses host gene expression through a number of unknown mechanisms 46 We note that out of 332 interactions, 60 are RBPs (as reported in Uniprot 39 ), which represents a 261 considerable fraction (i.e., 20%), considering that there are around 1500 RBPs in the human 262 proteome (i.e., 6%) and fully justified by the fact that they involve association with viral RNA. 263

Comparing the RBPs present in Gordon et al. 57 and those present in our list (79 as in Uniprot), we 264 found an overlap of 6 proteins (representation factor = 26.5; p-value < 10 -8 ; hypergeometric test), 265 including: Janus kinase and microtubule-interacting protein 1 JAKMIP1 (Q96N16), A-kinase 266 anchor protein 8 AKAP8 (O43823) and A-kinase anchor protein 8-like AKAP8L (Q9ULX6), which 267 in case of HIV-1 infection is involved as a DEAD/H-box RNA helicase binding 58 , signal 268 recognition particle subunit SRP72 (O76094), binding to the 7S RNA in presence of SRP68, La-269 related protein 7, LARP7 (Q4G0J3) and La-related protein 4B LARP4B (Q92615), which are part 270 of a system for transcriptional regulation acting by means of the 7SK RNP system 59 ( Fig. 4F ; 271
Supp. Table 2) . Interestingly, SRP72, LARP7 and LARP4B proteins assemble in stress granules 272 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.28.013789 doi: bioRxiv preprint 60-62 that are the targeted by RNA viruses 50 . We speculate that sequestration of these elements is 273 orchestrated by a viral program aiming to recruit host genes 46 . Heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein Q HNRNPQ and Nucleolin NCL 40 . In addition, we 367 discovered that the highly structured region at the 5' has the largest number of protein partners 368 including ATP-dependent RNA helicase DDX1, which was previously reported to be essential for 369 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Interactions between each fragment of target sequence and the human proteome were predicted 453 using catRAPID omics 18, 19 , an algorithm that estimates the binding propensity of protein-RNA 454 pairs by combining secondary structure, hydrogen bonding and van der Waals contributions. FIGREF0.text: comparisons reveal that the spike S region of SARS-CoV-2 is conserved among 126 SARS-CoV-2 than other coronaviruses (average structural content for SARS-CoV-2 = 141 0.56, indicating that 56% of the CROSS signal is >0, in the 5' and 0.49 in the 3'; by contrast, and structural comparisons among SARS-CoV-2 strains indicate conservation of 146 the ACE2 binding site and high variability in a region potentially interacting with sialic acids. 147 148 To better investigate the sequence conservation of SARS-CoV-2, we compared 62 strains isolated 149 from different countries during the pandemic (including China, USA, Japan, Taiwan, India, Brazil, 150 Sweden, and Australia; data from NCBI and in VIPR www.viprbrc.org; Materials and Methods). 151Our analysis aims to determine the relationship between structural content and

FIGREF1.text: DNA-binding proteins such as Cyclin-T1 CCNT1 (O60563), Zinc finger protein 175 ZNF175 222 (Q9Y473) and Prospero homeobox protein 1 PROX1 (Q92786) were included because they could 223 have potential RNA-binding ability (Fig. 4E) 41 . As for fragment 2, we found two canonical RBPs: 224 E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase TRIM32 (Q13049) and E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase TRIM21 (P19474), 225 which are listed as negative regulators of viral release from host cell, negative regulators of viral 226 transcription and positive regulators of viral entry into host cells. Finally, 10 of the 11 viral proteins 227 detected for fragment 29 are members of the Gag polyprotein family, that perform different tasks 228 during HIV assembly, budding, maturation. More than simple scaffold elements, Gag proteins are 229 versatile elements that bind to viral and host proteins as they traffic to the cell membrane (Supp. 230

FIGREF2.text: the host cell. Supporting this hypothesis, DXX1 and CCNT1 have been shown to 241 condense in large ribonucleoprotein assemblies such as stress granules 47-49 that are the primary 242 target of RNA viruses 50 . Regarding the function of these proteins in disease, DDX1 is required for 243 HIV-1 Rev as well as for avian coronavirus IBV replication and it binds to the RRE sequence of 244 HIV-1 RNAs 1-3 , while CCNT1 binds to 7SK snRNA and regulates transactivation domain of the 245 viral nuclear transcriptional activator, Tat 53,54 . 246 247 Analysis of SARS-CoV-2 proteins reveals common interactions 248 249 Recently, Gordon et al. reported a list of human proteins binding to Open Reading Frames (ORFs) 250 translated from SARS-CoV-2 57 . Identified through affinity purification followed by mass 251 spectrometry quantification, 332 proteins from HEK-293T cells interact with viral ORF peptides. 252By selecting 274 proteins binding at the 5' with Z score ³1.5 (Supp. Table 1), of which 140 are 253 exclusively interacting with fragment 1(Fig. 4B), we found that 8 are also reported in the list by 254 Gordon et al. 57 , which indicates significant enrichment (representation factor of 2.5; p-value of 255 0.02; hypergeometric test with human proteome in background). The fact that our list of protein-256 RNA binding partners contains elements identified also in the protein-protein network analysis is 257 not surprising, as ribonucleoprotein complexes evolve together 14 and their components sustain each 258 other through different types of interactions 16 . 259 260

FIGREF3.text: by directly analysing the RNA interaction potential of all the 332 proteins by Gordon et 276 al. 57 , catRAPID identified 38 putative binders at the 5' (Z score ³ 1.5; 27 occurring exclusively in 277 the 5' and not in other regions of the RNA) 18 , including Serine/threonine-protein kinase TBK1 278 (Q9UHD2), among which 10 RBPs (as reported in Uniprot) such as: Splicing elements U3 small 279 nucleolar ribonucleoprotein protein MPP10 (O00566) and Pre-mRNA-splicing factor SLU7 280 (O95391), snRNA methylphosphate capping enzyme MEPCE involved in negative regulation of 281 transcription by RNA polymerase II 7SK (Q7L2J0) 63 , Nucleolar protein 10 NOL10 (Q9BSC4) and 282 protein kinase A Radixin RDX (P35241; in addition to those mentioned above; Supp. Table 2). 283 284 HIV-related RBPs are significantly enriched in the 5' interactions 285 286 In the list of 274 proteins binding to the 5' (fragment 1) with Z score ≥1.5, we found 10 hits 287 associated with HIV (Supp. Table 3), which represents a significant enrichment (p-value=0.0004; 288 Fisher's exact test), considering that the total number of HIV-related proteins is 35 in the whole 289 catRAPID library (3340 elements). The complete list of proteins includes ATP-dependent RNA 290 helicase DDX1 (Q92499 also involved in Coronavirus replication 51,52 ), ATP-dependent RNA 291 helicase DDX3X (O00571 also involved in Dengue and Zika Viruses), Tyrosine-protein kinase 292 HCK (P08631, nucleotide binding), Arf-GAP domain and FG repeat-containing protein 1 (P52594), 293 Double-stranded RNA-specific editase 1 ADARB1 (P78563), Insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-294 binding protein 1 IGF2BP1 (Q9NZI8), A-kinase anchor protein 8-like AKAP8L (Q9ULX6; its 295 partner AKAP8 is also found in Gordon et al. 57 ) Cyclin-T1 CCNT1 (O60563; DNA-binding) and 296 Forkhead box protein K2 FOXK2 (Q01167; DNA-binding; Fig. 4B,E Supp.

FIGREF4.text: Phase-separating proteins are enriched in the 5' interactions 317 318 A number of proteins identified in our catRAPID calculations have been previously reported to 319 coalesce in large ribonucleoprotein assemblies such as stress granules. Among these proteins, we 320 found double-stranded RNA-activated protein kinase EIF2AK2 (P19525), Nucleolin NCL 321 (P19338), ATP-dependent RNA helicase DDX1 (Q92499), Cyclin-T1 CCNT1 (O60563), signal 322 recognition particle subunit SRP72 (O76094), LARP7 (Q4G0J3) and La-related protein 4B 323 LARP4B (Q92615) as well as Polypyrimidine tract-binding protein 1 PTBP1 (P26599) and 324 Heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein Q HNRNPQ (O60506) 62 . To further investigate the 325 propensity of these proteins to phase separate in stress granules, we used the catGRANULE 326 algorithm (Materials and Methods) 65 . We found that the 274 proteins binding to the 5' (fragment 327 1) with Z score ≥1.5 are highly prone to accumulate in stress-granules (274 proteins with the lowest 328 Z score are used in the comparison; p-value<0.0001; Kolmogorov-Smirnoff; Fig. 4G; Supp.

FIGREF5.text: CROSS 13,67 to compare the structural properties of 2800 coronaviruses and identified 342 elements conserved in SARS-CoV-2 strains. The regions containing the highest amount of structure 343 are the 5' as well as glycoproteins spike S and membrane M. 344 345 We found that the spike S protein domain encompassing amino acids 330-500 is highly conserved 346 across SARS-CoV-2 strains. This result suggests that spike S must have evolved to specifically 347 interact with its host partner ACE2 30 and mutations increasing the binding affinity are highly 348 infrequent. As the nucleic acids encoding for this region are enriched in double-stranded content, 349 we speculate that the structure might attract host regulatory elements, thus further constraining the 350 variability. The fact that the Spike S region is highly conserved among all the analysed SARS-CoV-351 2 strains suggests that a specific drug can be designed against it to prevent interactions within , the highly variable region at amino acids 243-302 in spike S protein corresponds to the 355 binding site of sialic acids in MERS-CoV (see manuscript by E. Milanetti et al.) 7,10,34 and could 356 play a role in infection 33 . The fact that the binding region changes in the different strains might 357 indicate a variety of binding affinities for sialic acids, which could provide clues on the specific 358 responses in the human population. Interestingly, the sialic acid binding site is absent in SARS-CoV 359 but present in MERS-CoV, which represents an important difference between the diseases. 360 361 Both our sequence and structural analyses of spike S protein indicate high conservation among 362 coronaviruses and suggest that human engineering of SARS-CoV-2 is highly unlikely. 363 364 Using catRAPID 18,19 we computed >100000 protein interactions with SARS-CoV-2 and found 365 previously reported interactions such as Polypyrimidine tract-binding protein 1 PTBP1, 366

FIGREF6.text: of the HDP-RNP complex interacting with ATP-dependent RNA helicase DHX9 373 68 and 2-5A-dependent ribonuclease RNASEL that has antiviral effects through a combination of 374 cleavage of single-stranded viral RNAs, inhibition of protein synthesis, induction of apoptosis, overlap exists with the list of protein interactions reported by Gordon et al. 57 , and 378 among the candidate partners we identified AKAP8L, involved as a DEAD/H-box RNA helicase 379 binding protein involved in HIV infection 58 . In general, proteins associated with retroviral 380 replication are expected to play different roles in SARS-CoV-2. As SARS-CoV-2 massively 381 represses host gene expression 46 , we hypothesize that the virus hijacks host pathways by recruiting 382 transcriptional and post-transcriptional elements interacting with polymerase II genes and splicing 383 factors such as for instance La-related protein 7 LARP7 and A-kinase anchor protein 8-like 384 AKAP8L. The link to proteins previously studied in the context of HIV and other viruses, if 385 confirmed experimentally, is particularly relevant for the repurposing of existing drugs 64 . 386 387The idea that SARS-CoV-2 sequesters different elements of the transcriptional machinery is 388 particularly intriguing and is supported by the fact that a large number of proteins identified in our 389 screening are found in stress granules 62 . Indeed, stress granules protect the host innate immunity 390 and are hijacked by viruses to favour their own replication 66 . Moreover, as coronaviruses 391 transcription uses discontinuous RNA synthesis that involves high-frequency recombination 40 , it is 392 possible that pieces of the viruses resulting from a mechanism called defective interfering RNAs 70 393 could act as scaffold to attract host proteins 14,

FIGREF7.text: Contributions. GGT and RDP conceived the study. AV carried out catRAPID analysis of protein 410 interactions, RDP calculated CROSS structures of coronaviruses, GGT, MM and EM performed and 411 analysed sequence alignments, JR, EZ and EB analysed the prediction results. AV, RDP and GGT 412 wrote the paper. 413 414 The authors do not have conflicts of interests. the secondary structure of transcripts using CROSS (Computational Recognition of 421 Secondary Structure 13,67 . CROSS was developed to perform high-throughput RNA profiling. The 422 algorithm predicts the structural profile (single-and double-stranded state) at single-nucleotide 423 resolution using sequence information only and without sequence length restrictions (scores > 0 424 indicate double stranded regions). We used the Vienna method 27 to further investigate the RNA 425 secondary structure of minima and maxima identified with CROSS 13 . CROSSalign 13,67 an algorithm based on Dynamic Time Warping (DTW), to check and 430 evaluate the structural conservation between different viral genomes 13 . CROSSalign was 431 previously employed to study the structural conservation of ~5000 HIV genomes. SARS-CoV-2 432 fragments (1000 nt, not overlapping) were searched inside other complete genomes using the OBE 433 (open begin and end) module, in order to search a small profile inside a larger one. The lower the 434 structural distance, the higher the structural similarities (with a minimum of 0 for almost identical 435 secondary structure profiles). The significance is assessed as in the original publication 13 sequences of the complete genomes of SARS-CoV-2 were downloaded from Virus 440 Pathogen Resource (VIPR; www.viprbrc.org), for a total of 62 strains. Regarding the overall 441 coronaviruses, the sequences were downloaded from NCBI selecting only complete genomes, for a 442 total of 2862 genomes. The reference Wuhan sequence with available annotation 443 (EPI_ISL_402119) was downloaded from Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data.

FIGREF8.text: 455 reported in a recent analysis of about half a million of experimentally validated interactions 31 , the 456 algorithm is able to separate interacting vs non-interacting pairs with an area under the ROC curve 457 of 0.78. The complete list of interactions between the 30 fragments and the human proteome is 458 available at http://crg-webservice.s3.amazonaws.com/submissions/2020-459 03/252523/output/index.html?unlock=f6ca306af0. The output then is filtered according to the Z-460 score column, which is the interaction propensity normalised by the mean and standard deviation 461 calculated over the reference RBP set (http://s.tartaglialab.com/static_files/shared/faqs.html#4). We 462 used three different thresholds in ascending order of stringency: Z greater or equal than 1.50, 1.75 463 and 2 respectively and for each threshold we then selected the proteins that were unique for each 464 fragment for each threshold. 465 466 GO terms analysis 467 468 cleverGO 38 , an algorithm for the analysis of Gene Ontology annotations, was used to determine 469 which fragments present enrichment in GO terms related to viral processes. Analysis of functional 470 annotations was performed in parallel with GeneMania 43 . 471 472 RNA and protein alignments 473 474 We used Clustal W 28 for 62 SARS-CoV-2 strains alignments and T-Coffee 32 for spike S proteins 475 alignments. The variability in the spike S region was measured by computing Shannon entropy on 476 translated RNA sequences. The Shannon entropy is computed as followsa correspond to the amino acid at the position i and P(a,i) is the frequency of a certain 481 amino-acid a at position i of the sequence. Low entropy indicates poorly variability: if P(a,x) = 1 for 482 one a and 0 for the rest, then S(x) =0. By contrast, if the frequencies of all amino acids are equally 483 distributed, the entropy reaches its maximum possible value. 484 that a protein is prone to phase separate. Md 1950 172, 381-391 (2004). 613 Using the CROSS approach 13,67 , we studied the structural content of SARS-CoV-2. We 654 found the highest density of double-stranded regions in the 5' (nucleotides 1-253), membrane M 655 protein (nucleotides 26523-27191), and the spike S protein (nucleotides 23000-24000). Strong 656 match is observed between CROSS and Vienna analyses (centroid structures shown), indicating 657 that regions with the highest structural content have the lowest free energies. 658 We employed the CROSSalign approach 13,67 to compare the Wuhan strain MN908947 with 660 other coronaviruses (1387 strains, including SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV) indicates that the most 661 conserved region falls inside the spike S genomic locus. The inset shows thermodynamic structural 662 variability (positional entropy) within regions encompassing nucleotides 23000-24000 along with 663 the centroid structure and free energy. 664 Sequence and structural comparison of human SARS-CoV-2 strains. (A) Strong sequence 666 conservation (Clustal W multiple sequence alignments 38 ) is observed in coding regions, including 667 the region between nucleotides 23000 and 24000 of spike S protein. High structural variability (red 668 bars on top) is observed for both the UTRs and for nucleotides between 21000 and 22000 as well as 669 24000 and 25000, associated with the S region. The rest of the regions are significantly conserved 670 at a structural level. (B) The sequence variability (Shannon entropy computed on T-Coffee multiple 671 sequence alignments 32 ) in the spike S protein indicate conservation between amino-acids 460 and 672 520 (blue box) binding to the host receptor angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 ACE2. The region 673 encompassing amino-acids 243 and 302 is highly variable and is implicated in sialic acids in 674 MERS-CoV (red box). The S1 and S2 domains of Spike S protein are displayed. 675 Characterization of protein interactions with SARS-CoV-2 RNA. (A) In agreement with 677 studies on coronaviruses 35 , PTBP1 shows the highest interaction propensity at the 5' and 678 HNRNPQ at 3' (indicated by red bars). (B) Number of RBP interactions for different SARS-CoV-2 679 regions (colours indicate catRAPID 18,19 confidence levels: Z=1.5 or low Z=1.75 or medium and 680 Z=2.0 or high; regions with scores lower than Z=1.5 are omitted); (C) Enrichment of viral 681 processes in the 5' of SARS-CoV-2 (precision = term precision calculated from the GO graph 682 structure lvl = depth of the term; go_term = GO term identifier, with link to term description at 683 AmiGO website; description = label for the term; e/d = enrichment / depletion compared to the 684 population; %_set = coverage on the provided set; %_pop = coverage of the same term on the 685 author/funder. No reuse allowed without permission.The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.28.013789 doi: bioRxiv preprint Very importantly, specific chemical compounds have been developed to interact with HIV-and 308 HVB-related proteins. The list of HIV-related targets reported in ChEMBL 64 includes ATP-309 dependent RNA helicase DDX1 (CHEMBL2011807), ATP-dependent RNA helicase DDX3X 310 (CHEMBL2011808), Cyclin-T1 CCNT1 (CHEMBL2348842), and Tyrosine-protein kinase HCK 311 (CHEMBL2408778) 64 , among other targets. In addition, HVB-related targets are Nuclear receptor 312 subfamily 5 group A member 2 NR5A2 (CHEMBL3544), Interferon-induced, double-stranded 313 RNA-activated protein kinase EIF2AK2 (CHEMBL5785) and SRSF protein kinase 1 SRPK1 314 (CHEMBL4375). We hope that this list can be the starting point for further pharmaceutical studies. 315

TABREF3.text: ). 330 331 This finding is particularly relevant because RNA viruses are known to antagonize stress granules 332 formation 50 . Indeed, the role of stress granules and processing bodies in translation suppression and 333 RNA decay have impact on virus replication 66 . 334 335 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.Our study is motivated by the need to identify molecular mechanisms involved in Covid-19 338 spreading. Using advanced computational approaches, we investigated the structural content of 339 SARS-CoV-2 RNA and predicted human proteins that bind to it.
